repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Kurunegala and Second Rural
            Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the Kurunegala and
            Second Rural Development Project for Sri Lanka. It assesses
            the outcome, impact, and sustainability of the major
            productive components of the two projects. From a
            quantitative and qualitative viewpoint, it found the
            projects' performance to be mixed. The ERRs (Economic
            Rate for Return) for the productive components were
            generally below the traditional cutoff point for a
            satisfactory rating. In addition, the quality of the initial
            rehabilitation works was poor and the subsequent O&M
            (Operation and Maintenance) insufficient. The primary
            problems behind the poor performance were: 1) overly
            optimistic SAR targets; 2) over-attribution of production
            increases to project actions; and 3) lack of beneficiary
            involvement, poor supervision, and an absence of
            transitional planning. Despite these shortcomings, some
            success did emerge. First, paddy yields in the small
            irrigation schemes rehabilitated under the projects proved
            to be above average for the districts and had increased more
            rapidly than in the country as a whole. Second, the
            infrastructure projects provided significant benefits.
            Lastly, the line agencies involved in implementing the
            projects expanded their implementation capacity
            considerably. Overall, the impact of the projects can be
            considered marginally satisfactory.

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Second Rural Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Rural
            Development Project for Sri Lanka was successful. The main
            objective, to improve the productivity, income, and living
            standards of people in the Puttalam and Matale districts,
            was achieved. Implementation of the project was deemed
            satisfactory even though there were delays. The project is
            sustainable for the future. Both the Borrower and the Bank
            acted effectively. Several lessons can be learned from this
            experience. First, the project confirms that the approach
            taken to achieve a broad-based development of Sri
            Lanka's districts, initiated under the Kurunegala Rural
            Development Project, is appropriate and replicable under the
            country's conditions. Second, project design should
            have focused more clearly on organization and management
            aspects to ensure effective coordination among the multiple
            line agencies. Third, the project would have been easier to
            supervise if it did not include such a wide and diverse
            range of subprojects. Lastly, the project period should have
            been longer than envisaged due to implementation delays that
            arose when a large number of agencies were involved and
            funds were in short supply.

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Second Rural Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Development Project
            aims to assist in developing the districts of Matale and
            Puttalam by raising productivity, employment, incomes and
            living standards. The project will: (i) improve the
            provision of inputs and services required for the directly
            productive sectors; (ii) increase plantings of coconut and
            minor export crops; (iii) rehabilitate and improve economic
            infrastructure; and (iv) improve social infrastructure. The
            project will benefit about 130,000 farm families, about
            two-thirds of these families being in the poverty target
            groups. The project design closely follows the model
            developed for the Kurunegala Rural Development Project
            (Credit No. 891). The project suffers from inherent risks
            associated with such a multi-component project and faces
            difficulties associated with actions in politically
            sensitive and institutionally demanding areas. However, such
            risks are reduced by the successful experience with
            decentralized system in the above-mentioned Kurunegala project.
